text:
I've made this pie three times now, and it's always made a delicious pie.  However, I had an epiphany before making it this last time that greatly improved the result.  I've been adding a tbs of cinnamon as was recommended by other reviewers, but made the mistake of adding the cinnamon to the sauce.  The pie tasted fine, but the presentation didn't seem as impressive as people raved about.  It was dark brown and unappealing.  This last time, it occured to me that the cinnamon was making the pie turn dark, so instead of mixing the cinnamon into the sauce, I mixed it into the apples in a bowl before pouring the apples into the crust.  The sauce I prepared as stated in the recipe.  The resulting pie was picture perfect in its presentation, and cinnamon taste was just as good.  So remember, if you want to add cinnamon, add it to the apples, not the sauce.

This last time, it occured to me that the cinnamon was making the pie turn dark, so instead of mixing the cinnamon into the sauce, I mixed it into the apples in a bowl before pouring the apples into the crust. text:
OK, you've probably read many reviews as to  how delicious this pie is (and it really is!).  What you've also read is the submitter forgot to list the cinnamon in the recipe or how you should forgo the lattice crust and a few other suggestions.  

Let me strongly suggest that you try this recipe unaltered at least once.  The  point is that this is a small twist on traditional apple pie, so no cinnamon (or nutmeg or cloves or raisins etc.).  The lattice crust is essential because it lets you pour the caramel mixture over the top and it drains into the fresh apples underneath while leaving a thin coat on the lattice crust.  It really isn't hard to do...there's even a short video of a teenager making a lattice crust pie for a dinner in honor of his mom's visiting friend.  Check it out if you need some pointers.

I also saw comments suggesting to use 6 apples instead of 8.  Another suggestion I saw several times said to just put the pie in at 350 degrees for 1 hour and it's fine.  I would say if you are using an 8" pie dish, sure, reduce it down to 6 apples but for a 9" dish, 8 apples was just right (I could have probably squeezed in one more).  I would also strongly suggest following the baking instructions because the higher temperature helps set the bottom of the crust.  With fresh fruit pies, there  is a chance the crust will not fully bake in the center as the fruit releases liquid.  The high temperatures "temper" the crust during the first 15 minutes of baking.  

Finally,

Let me strongly suggest that you try this recipe unaltered at least once.  The  point is that this is a small twist on traditional apple pie, so no cinnamon (or nutmeg or cloves or raisins etc.).  The lattice crust is essential because it lets you pour the caramel mixture over the top and it drains into the fresh apples underneath while leaving a thin coat on the lattice crust.  It really isn't hard to do...there's even a short video of a teenager making a lattice crust pie for a dinner in honor of his mom's visiting friend.  Check it out if you need some pointers.

I also saw comments suggesting to use 6 apples instead of 8.  Another suggestion I saw several times said to just put the pie in at 350 degrees for 1 hour and it's fine. Finally,

text:
There's no need to keep looking around for an apple pie recipe.  This one is delicious.  I modified it slightly based on other reviews. Use 6 apples (instead of 8) and you'll have plenty. Instead of pouring the sauce on top of the pie crust, I just mixed it in with the apples.  Additionally, I added
1 tsp. cinnamon, 1/2 tsp. nutmeg and 1 tsp. vanilla to apples.  To make my life easier, I used the Pilsbury ready-made pie crust and I didn't do the lattice top.  Instead, I just made slits in the pie crust, brushed a thin coating of milk over the top and sprinkled with sugar.  Don't forget to put a cookie sheet under the pie dish when baking--it will overflow!  Lastly, I thought my apples turned out perfectly extending the cooking time at 350 to 50 minutes.  Please enjoy this recipe!!!

text:
Few notes to those having performance problems with this pie: Use a variety of apples, Granny Smith plus one or two sweeter types of apples (McIntosh is good)if you're finding it to be too tart or too firm. Makes it less tart if that's a problem, plus some apples break down more than G. Smiths. So end product should be not too tart, not too firm, and not too mushy. If your crust is turning out mushy on the bottom, you probably know to brush it with milk or egg first to prevent liquid from seeping into the dough, but another help is to place the pie into a (cool) cast iron skillet before putting in the oven. Putting the pie on the bottom rack (or floor of the oven itself if you have a gas oven) also helps bake the bottom crust. If it's too runny for you, use flour, potato or corn starch, ClearJel or some other thickener. No shame- it's pretty standard apple pie baking procedure! There are too many positive reviews to reject this as a "bad recipe" before doing some troubleshooting!

Few notes to those having performance problems with this pie: Use a variety of apples, Granny Smith plus one or two sweeter types of apples (McIntosh is good)if you're finding it to be too tart or too firm. Makes it less tart if that's a problem, plus some apples break down more than G. Smiths. So end product should be not too tart, not too firm, and not too mushy. If your crust is turning out mushy on the bottom, you probably know to brush it with milk or egg first to prevent liquid from seeping into the dough, but another help is to place the pie into a (cool) cast iron skillet before putting in the oven. Putting the pie on the bottom rack (or floor of the oven itself if you have a gas oven) also helps bake the bottom crust. If it's too runny for you, use flour, potato or corn starch, ClearJel or some other thickener. No shame- it's pretty standard apple pie baking procedure! text:
absolutely divine!!!!  This is the recipe I will use from now on.  The only mods. I made were to add a tsp of vanilla to the heated mixture, used a variety of different semi-crisp and crisp apples tossed in a tbsp. of lemon juice, and of course, cinnamon and nutmeg. I also added 1/2 tsp salt to the butter, as I think that salt does tend to bring out a little flavor in the apple and I only had unsalted butter. I am not good at lattice tops so I followed the others that just added the mixture to their apples and placed in pan followed by the top crust.  Just superb!!!  thanks so much for this recipe.  It sure is a keeper with the addition of spices....can't have apple pie without the spice. **I am assuming this is a deep-dish pie?  I purchased 7 very large apples of different varieties instead of one bag that are usually small in size, and I had to put this in my deep dish pieplate and it was mounded nicely.  Keep in mind that apples do lose juice, therefore during baking there will be shrinking so always mound apples up nicely before putting on top crust.

text:
My family hovers to see who can sit closest to this pie every Thanksgiving.  To make it easier on yourself, use 1 less apple, pour most of the sauce over the apples before putting on the crust, then drizzle remaining sauce over the lattice, then cover crust edge with foil until last 20 min (trust me on this one).  Cook on a cookie sheet as sauce will drip out!  I don't have lots of time, so I use the refridgerator crusts & with the addition of the sauce it comes out great!  For our tastes I add lots of cinnamon.

text:
This was my first time to make any kind of pie and it turned out great.  I was so proud of it.  I made it for my fiancee's family and everyone loved it...there wasn't any left!  I did the lattice crust which was surprisingly really easy.  I also added the cinnamon vanilla and a touch of nutmeg as recommended.  I used 1 less apple than the recipe calls for..but probably could have fit it in if I really tried. I also brushed the bottom of the pie with egg whites before putting the apples in and cooked that for about 5 minutes so the bottom wouldn't get mushy.  I used a "crust saver" that I got at the store to keep the pie from over flowing and the crust from burning.  I also mixed the apples in the sauce and poured it all in together...then brushed the remaining 1/4th of the sauce on the top.
I can't wait to make it tonight for our thanksgiving party at work.

I did the lattice crust which was surprisingly really easy.  I also added the cinnamon vanilla and a touch of nutmeg as recommended. text:
I am a retired professional chef and I have never had an apple pie like this apple pie! It is amazing! I like to toss the apples with cinnamon and instead of 1/4 cup of water alone, I use half bourbon and half water. Also...I suggest adding  1/4 teaspoon of salt. Many people don't realize that adding just a touch of salt to sweet dishes helps to bring out the flavor!  But no matter what alterations you do to this pie, the magic is in its preparation! Pouring the liquid over the latticework crust creates a crunchy topping while the liquid that bakes with the apples almost caramelizes. In fact, I almost wanted to call this "caramel apple pie".  What a great submission! By far and away this is THE best apple pie I have ever tasted!

My Great Grandmother and her children (my Grandmother and Great Aunt) were the best cooks and they loved to fill your belly. I am proud to see all the rave reviews and hope that you will try this recipe and enjoy it as much as we did and do to this day. Also a note try it as is the first time it is perfect the way it is but if you feel that you still need to modify it or tweak it to your own. that's cool!  Thanks to all! and I love you, Great Grandma, Grandma, and Nanny.

text:
I had never made an apple pie in my life, but using this recipe, I won my county's Ag Fair Apple Pie Contest!! I did use Red Delicious apples, as I am not too fond of Granny Smiths. Also, I made one batch of the sauce and mixed it in with apples before adding into bottom crust. Then, AFTER I did the lattice on top crust, I made ANOTHER batch of sauce and poured over top of pie, using as much as needed. I made this pie before the contest and took slices around to friends and family members and told them, "here, taste this and tell me what you think". Everybody raved and I was hoping they weren't just being nice. I made another pie the morning of the contest, figuring I had nothing to lose. I must say- I was really surprised when I was announced as the winner and now this will be the ONLY apple pie recipe I will ever use!

text:
My husband and I always argue about whether or not a recipe should be tried for the first time as it is written.  I am the one who says, "Yes"!  After that, the cook is free to tweak it according to personal taste.  This pie got rave revues without cinnamon or other spices and without any other changes whatsoever.  Why trifle with perfection?  Anyway, those of you who are experiencing runniness, may be using "salted" butter instead of what the recipe suggests.  Osmosis may be contributing to extra juices being extruded from the apples.  I have never had a problem with this, and I attribute it to using unsalted butter.  As a diabetic, I have tried the recipe using the half Splenda/half white or brown sugar substitutions and find that no one seems to know the difference.  This pie is so fast and easy and delicious.  I have shared the recipe with many to date.

text:
This is by far the best apple pie i've ever had. Just an afterthought, the finished product looks nothing like that picture submitted for this recipe. It has a delicious, golden brown lattice crust glistening with brown sugar and butter. Yum, it's so good! 

There is however, one HUGE problem with this recipe. The submitter forgot to add a very neccesary ingredient, cinnamon! I just add it to taste in a large bowl with the sliced, peeled apples and mix to incorporate before adding to the crust.

text:
My family loved this recipe. I combined a family recipie for the apple filling with the rest of the recipe.  
 I have a few suggestions...
1.  I made the filling with 2 TBS cornstarch, 1 cup sugar, 1 cup brown sugar and 2 tsp pumpkin pie spice.

2.  make sure your pie is ready with tha apples in it and the top crust on before you start with the sauce ontop.  I made this mistake and the sauce came out hard.
3.  The "looser" you pile your apples in the pie the more "room" you have for the sauce to sink in.
4.  Before pouring the sauce on, place a cooling rack over your sink so its suspended.  Then SLOWLY pour the sauce.  The slower you pour the more stuff with get inside the pie.
5.  Make sure to have a cookie sheet under the pie.  IT WILL DRIP.  I lined my cookie sheet with foil so I can change out the foil when it start to burn.
6.  I also used 1/4 cup apple cider instead of the 1/4 cup water
Review:

5

text:
I followed the recipe as directed. And I also followed the suggestion of 1 reviewer: I added 1teaspoon of cinnamon to the apples after I was done slicing them, & I brushed egg white on the crusts. I didn't make my own crust. I bought 1 box of Betty Croker pie crust mix. And even though the pie was great, next time I'll buy 2 boxes of Betty Crocker b/c 1 box wasn't enough. The bottom crust was too thin, but the lattice top was fine. I poured the filling onto the apples & saved 1/4 of a cup of it to pour some over the top crust. Overall, the pie was delicious! This was my first time baking a pie & it was my practice pie b/c I'm making it for Thanksgiving this year.

text:
I just love this pie, as do all of the people who gets a slice.  I use Pillsbury frozen pie crust (deep dish) for the bottom crust and Pillsbury refrigerated crust for the lattice top.  Like others, I substitute the water for brandy or cognac.  You may have to add a bit of extra liquid if you use liquor.  And also like others, I think it's much easier to mix the apples with the sauce before placing in the pie pan.  This truly is a fabulous apple pie.

text:
I was always intimidated by baking pies.  I decided to try this recipe and I'm glad I did.  I made this pie four times over the holidays last year and plan to make it again this year.  Unless you have small apples, 8 apples is way too many.  I found that 4 medium sized apples fills the crust adequately.  If you want an overstuffed pie, 6 medium sized apples should suffice.

text:
Thank you Grandma Ople!  Her tradition carries on through each and every holiday.  We love this recipe, I do add 1 teaspoon of cinnamon - I mix it into the apples rather than the sauce.  I combine the apples with 1/2 the sauce then put it in the shell.  I top with lattice and pour and brush the remainder on.  I use the premade rolled out crusts when I'm pressed for time and I can't tell the difference between those and homemade - not like the frozen crusts that come in the pan.  Thank you for a new tradition!  Update - I won the first place in the pie competition at our County fair this year with this recipe - it's a winner!

text:
I don't like pie and I loved this recipe! I made mine by using one of each different kind of apple I could find, fuji, granny smith and two other kinds I can't remember names. I put them in a bowl and sprinkled with 1tsp cinnimon and 1tsp nutmeg then tossed. Poured most of mixture in and tossed again then put in ready made crust. I drizzled the rest of the mixture (sugars) over the top of the crust and it baked beautifully! I did the 15 minutes at 425 then 30 at 350 then I turned the oven off and let it sit. So yummy!

text:
Apple will never make it into my top ten favorite pies, however, I do make them for my family. I always taste what I make and I'm happy to say that grandma Ople certainly knows her way around a kitchen. This recipe is absolutely wonderful. Read many of the reviews and took others advice. I used a combo of various types of apples, apple juice in lieu of the water, added vanilla and apple pie spice to the mix, coated the apples with most of the sauce, did not lattice the top crust but brushed it with the remaining sauce. The glaze created a light and crispy top crust and a very flavorable pie. Thanks so much Rebecca!

None
text:
I used this recipe for a pie contest at work and won!  I did modify it a little bit.  I add cinnamon and vanilla to the apples before adding them to the pan.  Once the apples are in the pan I take carmel ice cream topping and drizzle it on top of the apples.  I don't use a lattice crust; I use a full top crust and I add the sugar and butter mixture to the apples before putting the top crust on.  Once I have the top crust on, I brush it with an egg and sprinkle with sugar.  Yum Yum!

text:
This recipe is absolutely perfect AS IS! I know people are recommending cinnamon, and yes, a traditional apple pie has cinnamon ... however, this is not your traditional apple pie. It's BETTER! I make the pies for every holiday gathering (Thanksgiving, Christmas, Easter) and apple is always a family favorite. I usually use a family recipe but this Thanksgiving tried this recipe for a new twist. The ENTIRE family said it was the best apple pie they had ever had. I had to agree. I know you're tempted to use less apples, add in some other ingredients, change the lattice work, etc, but I beg you not to! Try it out just as it is and you won't be disappointed. I promise!

text:
This is my favorite apple pie recipe.  I add spices to the butter mixture like others do.  I also mix the apples with the butter before putting it in the pie shell.  Here's my trick to ensure I get the carmelizing on the crust.  All I do is reserve a little of the butter after mixing it with the apples.  Then I brush that over the top pie crust.  This way, I know the mixture has gotten all the way thru the filling, but also get the look I want on top.

text:
What a wonderful apple pie recipe, I've made this about 4 times now and each time it's delicious and I get so many compliments! I make some minor changes though. I toss the apples with cinnamon, nutmeg, and a dash of cloves, and pour  the caramel sauce over the apples, instead of over a lattice crust, which I baste with egg yolk. I used the "French Pastry Pie Crust" from this Website which worked perfectly. A scrumptious apple pie, I was worried it was going to be a bit dry but it wasn't at all, the sauce made it really special and moist, but not too moist. The apples weren't soggy either, I use between 6 and 7 apples, which is plenty. My mother in law asked me to translate the recipe into German for her! I have also made this pie with rhubarb and apples, and strawberry-rhubarb. That worked very well too!

text:
The foundation of the pie is very good.  I use my own basic pie crust recipe (doubled) with added cinnamon to it.  I reduced the water to 1/8th of a cup and also added cinnamon to the mixture.  Prior to adding the apples to the dough, I bake the bottom portion for 10 minutes so it would not become soggy.  If you use many apples as I do, place the pie on top of a cookie sheet to prevent the butter etc. from leaking out of the pie into your oven.

None
text:
This was delicious.  I followed this almost exactly.  I like things sweeter, so I added some brown sugar to the top of the apples and sprinkled with more cinnamon and added a few pats of butter.  When pouring the mixture over the top you have to go VERY slowly.  The next time I make this pie I will toss the apples around in the mixture first and reserve some for the top.  Don't miss that step because it makes a fabulous carmel like glaze to the crust.  And don't forget a drip pan! Great recipe.

this was my first attempt at making apple pie. it turned out amazing. i made 2 of them. the first i followed the recipe but added half teaspoon each of cinnamon and nutmeg and 1 teaspoon vanilla to apples. was amazing. the second i put the spices and the sauce with the apples saved a little and brushed on top of pie. either way is great. also to prevent soggy crust, i prebaked the bottom crust at 350 for about 5 minutes and it was not at all soggy. put strips of foil around edges of top crust to prevent burning. if i can make pie this good anyone can. thanks grandma ople

text:
Cindy of 11/9/09--This pie is not what I expected given all the stars. It's okay but not all that.  There are two recipes for this pie just so you know.  One tells how long to simmer syrup, one doesn't.  I used the one with the 2400 or more reviews.  It doesn't.  I thought both were identical so I just clicked on this one to rate.  Thank the Lord because I thought I was going crazy reading this one's direction.  Though the simmer issue is moot.  No need to get all worked up over a rating.  You are suggesting a person have to lie just because someone took time to post a recipe??  If I didn't like it...I didn't like it.  It wasn't runny, it held up...but the taste was just okay. I am a seasoned cook...not a chef...but a seasoned cook.  I followed THAT recipe from 'A' to 'Y' with 'Z' being the spice that I added.   If I had not added spice...this rating would have ben a 1 at best.  Since I DO know how to cook...nothing failed with pie. It's just ok!  When I see this many stars...I just expected a lot more.  You must be a relative but be advised to breath...it's not that serious. You responded to my previous comment/rating (this one replaced unfortunately) with wierd & hurt feelings over a recipe I have every right to rate. This apple pie is palatable at best for my taste so no-- it wasn't a disaster but it was just....oooookay. I still think the pie would fair better cooking the apples IN this syrup as well but again that's my opinion. And thank goodness for it!

userID:
415567
Display Name:
sunnie
isPro:

7

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family is quite experienced with pie making (I've won blue a ribbon for my peach pie and my mother won a blue ribbon for her apple pie)and I think  this apple pie recipe (Grandma Ople's) is fabulous!  It's a little tricky to make because of the syrup, but very much worth the effort.  

I used a combination of Jonathan, MacIntosh, and Yellow Delicious apples and I also added 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon to the syrup. Be sure to stir the syrup constantly (I burned the first batch and had to make a second batch).  Also, don't boil the syrup too hard for the entire five minutes because I think it makes the syrup way too stiff - - almost like hard-tack candy.  Instead, just simmer like the instructions say (while stirring the entire time).  I poured the syrup over the apples in a large bowl before putting them into the shell.  The syrup did "clump up" when it hit the cold apples, but I made sure the clumps of syrup were  evenly distributed in the pastry shell so that when the pie baked, the syrup would melt and distribute evenly (which it did).  Be sure to put a large piece of aluminum foil on the oven shelf under the pie, as it will most likely drip a lot.  I didn't pour the syrup over the lattice crust (again, the syrup was too thick).  Instead, I sprinkled large-grain white sugar on top of the lattice crust. 

The pie was beautiful and delicious.  Everyone loved it.  It would give my mom's blue-ribbon apple pie a run for the money!    

I just wish I would have measured how many
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-11-29T09:39:55.313
helpfulCount:
5
userID:
415567
Display Name:
sunnie
isPro:
False

7

69

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2431944.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family is quite experienced with pie making (I've won blue a ribbon for my peach pie and my mother won a blue ribbon for her apple pie)and I think  this apple pie recipe (Grandma Ople's) is fabulous!  It's a little tricky to make because of the syrup, but very much worth the effort.  

I used a combination of Jonathan, MacIntosh, and Yellow Delicious apples and I also added 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon to the syrup. Be sure to stir the syrup constantly (I burned the first batch and had to make a second batch).  Also, don't boil the syrup too hard for the entire five minutes because I think it makes the syrup way too stiff - - almost like hard-tack candy.  Instead, just simmer like the instructions say (while stirring the entire time).  I poured the syrup over the apples in a large bowl before putting them into the shell.  The syrup did "clump up" when it hit the cold apples, but I made sure the clumps of syrup were  evenly distributed in the pastry shell so that when the pie baked, the syrup would melt and distribute evenly (which it did).  Be sure to put a large piece of aluminum foil on the oven shelf under the pie, as it will most likely drip a lot.  I didn't pour the syrup over the lattice crust (again, the syrup was too thick).  Instead, I sprinkled large-grain white sugar on top of the lattice crust. 

The pie was beautiful and delicious.  Everyone loved it.  It would give my mom's blue-ribbon apple pie a run for the money!    

I just wish I would have measured how many

text:
This was the first pie I'd ever made, and it came out a HUGE sucess!  I used store bought pie crust, coated it with a thin egg wash, then cooked it a few minutes to harden so it wouldn't get soggy from the topping.  Then, I followed the recipe, but added only half the caramel mixture to the apples.  I then took another softened store bought crust and cut it into strips, latticing atop the mound of apples.  I poured on the rest of the sweet sauce, before adding a finally sprinkling of white sugar to the top crust.  I cooked it about 35 minutes and then took it to my boyfriend's house (he's addicted to a. pie!), where we reheated it for a few minutes.  It cut easily and tasted DELICIOUS!  I don't even particularly care for any pies, but this is actually a new favorite food of mine!  I will make it many times again exactly as I stated before!

text:
I made this pie and it was picture perfect.  I made a few suggested alterations to the recipe and it was the best apple pie ever.  Alterations, are as follows:Prebaked bottom crust for 10 minutes at 350 after brushing with egg whites. Mixed 2 teaspoons of  cinnamon and 1 tablespoon of flour to the cut apples. After piling the apples in the shell, poured the syrup over the apples and reserved a little for later. Then put a full crust on top, cut slits, and brushed he top with the remaining syrup.
While baking, I put a cookie sheet underneath for fall out. Cooked same as recipe covering edge with foil after first 15 min. When done, turned off oven and let set for 15 more min in warm oven before removing pie.

Alterations, are as follows:Prebaked bottom crust for 10 minutes at 350 after brushing with egg whites. Mixed 2 teaspoons of  cinnamon and 1 tablespoon of flour to the cut apples. text:
The pie turned out great. I made it twice in two weeks - once as written and once with a little apple pie spice sprinkled on the apples which I preferred. I had no problems with a runny pie. I believe this is because I used the granny smith apples as called for. Tart apples have more pectin to them which prevents a runny pie. The tartness of the apples blended beautifully with the sugar syrup. Using sweet apples would probably yield a too-sweet runny pie. Thanks for the recipe - my family loved it.

country:
None
text:
This was my second apple pie and after reading all the reviews, I had to try it.  I LOVE THIS PIE and have found my apple pie recipe!  It turned  out just as expected and was much better than my first one (which was a different recipe). I used three Macintosh, two Granny Smith and two Braeburns. I sprinkled the apples with cinnamon and also added a TBSP of cinnamon & Vanilla extract to the syrup mixture.  I too mixed the apples with the syrup, then added them to the pie crust.  I was very careful not to add a lot of extra syrup to the pie (I shook the apples of extra liquid). I cheated and used Pillsbury frozen pie crust, but everytime I use it, my friends ask me if it's homemade!  I did not use the lattice top.  The only problem I had was that once I added the flour to the butter, it came out lumpy. I added water to the flour first and got all the lumps out, then added it to the butter as one reviewer suggested, but still no luck. I think my butter was too hot. Any suggestions?  Either way, the lumps became slightly smaller and still turned out great after pouring on apples.  Also, I followed the Pillsbury tip and pre-heated my cookie sheet while I was busy making the pie. This may be why I was able to avoid the extra liquid and mushy bottom that occurred with my first pie.  I think my pie will be gone in one day!
Review:

text:
I have made this pie 4 times since Thanksgiving and it has definitely been a hit. It is the first "fresh" apple pie I've ever made and each time it has come out looking like I've been making pies for years. Please go the "easy route" and buy Pillsbury "ready-made" crusts found in the "buscuit" section of the store--it comes with top and bottom crust and they work perfectly for this recipe.  I like to add 1 teaspoon cinnamon, but it is very good both ways.  Don't be afraid to pour the sugar paste on top of the lattice work crust.  It has come out perfect every time I've made it.  One thing I especially like about this pie is that the granny smith apples add the right amount of tartness to the sweetness of the sugar paste.  Thanks for a wonderful recipe!

I also recommend making the sauce AFTER everthing else is already ready, so you can just pour it on.  The first time I made it, I did the sauce first, and it cooled before I could pour it on, didn't make for such a great pie!  The second time I did it last, and it was FANTASTIC!

text:
It was really yummy!  I made it last Thanksgiving and will make it again this year.  Here are my modifications: a) double the liquid  b) I added some vanilla and cinnamon  c) I only used 6 apples, 3 granny smith and 3 others types mixed)  d) used apple juice instead of water  e) used splenda instead of sugar  f) brushed the pastry top with egg wash

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
If my boyfriend's comments are any testament to how wonderful this is, you have to try this if you're still on the fence.  He literally raved for 2 days - on and on about how this was the BEST apple pie he's ever had.  The pie didn't even last a full 24 hours.  I was skeptical because it didn't call for cinnamon and next time, I just may add it, but it's still wonderful without it.  As another reviewer aptly described, it's got a golden buttery taste. I used what apples I had (Ida Red)and opted to pour the butter mixture over the apples before I put the top crust on; seemed easier and less messy that way.  I'll also bake at 350 for the entire time so as to avoid burning the crust.  Thanks so much for posting this recipe!

text:
This recipe is on this site twice; under its other name it is "Apple Pie by Grandma Ople", which I made over the weekend. It's fantastic. If you need to see more tips and reviews, you can go look at the other version of this recipe to see the "top reviews" there too -- the recipes themselves are identical, but you may find more specific tips for you listed on that one :) We found this to be delicious, but a tiny bit runny. It sets up better after being refrigerated, but microwaving the slices causes it to become runny again. Tastes great, but doesn't present well! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This is a great apple pie recipe.  After making it as directed, I agree with other reviewers that the sauce should be poured over the apples and mixed together in a bowl first, before pouring into the pie crust.  Save a bit of the sauce to pour over the lattice that you make.  Truly scrumptious and best served warm with vanilla ice cream!

Display Name:
lisentume

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great pie...once I stuck to the origional recipe.  I made the mistake of putting in heavy cream for the water, which totally changed the taste of the pie. I made two pies; one w/ latice and one w/ a crumble topping.  The second time I made it, I did it exactly as directed w/ the exception of tossing the apples in cinnamon and 2 tsp vanilla.  A big diffrence in the pie is the apples: Granny Smith is too tart w/ no sweetness.  All the rest fall apart while baking and doesn't hold its sweetness.  The best apples to use are the Golden Delicious green apples; a little tartness w/ sweetness.  I also tossed in the sauce reserving a lttle for the topping.  I drizzled caramel across the top before placing the lattice.  Very good pie.  UPDATE:  To keep the pie from having juice all over the place, as well as a too juicy pie, add 2 tbsp of quick cooking tapioca to the apple mixture.  The pie will hold better.
Review:

This was a great pie...once I stuck to the origional recipe.  I made the mistake of putting in heavy cream for the water, which totally changed the taste of the pie. I made two pies; one w/ latice and one w/ a crumble topping.  The second time I made it, I did it exactly as directed w/ the exception of tossing the apples in cinnamon and 2 tsp vanilla.  A big diffrence in the pie is the apples: Granny Smith is too tart w/ no sweetness.  All the rest fall apart while baking and doesn't hold its sweetness.  The best apples to use are the Golden Delicious green apples; a little tartness w/ sweetness.  I also tossed in the sauce reserving a lttle for the topping.  I drizzled caramel across the top before placing the lattice.  Very good pie.  UPDATE:  To keep the pie from having juice all over the place, as well as a too juicy pie, add 2 tbsp of quick cooking tapioca to the apple mixture.  The pie will hold better.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This worked beautifully for me on the first try, using the tip from others to put most of the sauce on the apples, then brushing a bit over the lattice (since how much gets into the filling, runs off or sits on the top depends on how tightly you do your lattice - if I do a more open lattice next time, I'll just drizzle the sauce).  I sliced the Granny Smiths about 1/4 to 1/3-inch thick on average so they cooked through beautifully.  I had huge, local apples so I just filled the pie using what fit which was about 5 of these apples - I had to just see what fit in my particular pie plate so I did follow the directions - filled and mounded the apples slightly.  There are few recipes I feel like I'll stick with after the first try, but this is a definite!

How sweet it is!!!!  Today for the first time in my life, I had some hand picked apples from Ellijay Georgia.  So I began my search for a recipe, and stumbled upon this one. It was divine..mouth-watering and oh so sweet.  I did add cinnamon, and some nutmeg, but for the rest I stayed true to the recipe.  It came out purrrfect!  My crust was delicious, and the apples I used simply heavenly.  I will never use another recipe again.  This will always be on my table, and with each first bite, my appreciation goes out to Rebecca for sharing her Grandma Ople's apple pie recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best apple pie i've ever eaten in my life! I did make some changes thou. I upped the sauce by half and used 1 more tbs of flour than the recipe called for, used 5 Granny Smiths sliced thickly so that it'll be chewier, and added 2 tbs cinammon to the apples. I placed a layer of apples on the crust then poured some of the sauce over it then another layer of apples and the sauce, finishing it by spreading the sauce on the lattice top. I've got no problem with the sauce overflowing, probably bcos i used a 10 inch pan. I left it to cool for a while and the sauce settled nicely and firmly without being too messy. It looks picture perfect and the top crust was to die for!

text:
This was a hot for me!  I always laugh at people who alter recipes but I did the following: used pre-made crust, added some cinnamon to apples, no lattice top (just slits on regular pie top), added the syrup to apples before putting in pie shell and saved a bit to brush on top. I personally love the simplicity of the ingredients.  I had everything but a couple of apples and the crust!
A yummy treat for hubby and I.  Looking forward to leftovers and perhaps sharing with family for Thanksgiving!

I took SDTERP (May 2008) advice and made this pie per recipe...not modifications.  It was delicious!  It has a buttery caramel taste versus a spicey one.  Also, if you're like me and pie crusts have never been your strong suit, pouring the butter/sugar mixture over the lattice work top (Pillsbury ready made crust) makes the store bought crust taste SO good!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my very first review on allrecipes, this pie was so good, that I had to add to the already stellar raves. 
I used 7 small/medium sized Granny Smith apples, added a 1tablespoon of vanilla to the mix (and omitted a tablespoon of water like the many suggestions) and it was ah-mazing! When making the caramel sauce I melted the butter first as per the directions and then added the flour one spoonful at time, stirring in between to really incorporate it- I didn't let it boil, but made sure that all the sugar was dissolved. I tossed the apple slices in lemon juice and then added a little more than half of the sauce to them and gave them a stir before pouring them into the pie crust. I brushed the remaining sauce over the lattice top- just so we didn't miss out on the crust everyone was mentioning.
This pie was fantastic! I was a little afraid that it was going to be too sweet, but Grandma Ople sure knew what she was doing! Perfection. Thank you so much for sharing this recipe. It will be gracing many tables in the future!

text:
This is my very first review on allrecipes, this pie was so good, that I had to add to the already stellar raves. 
I used 7 small/medium sized Granny Smith apples, added a 1tablespoon of vanilla to the mix (and omitted a tablespoon of water like the many suggestions) and it was ah-mazing! When making the caramel sauce I melted the butter first as per the directions and then added the flour one spoonful at time, stirring in between to really incorporate it- I didn't let it boil, but made sure that all the sugar was dissolved. I tossed the apple slices in lemon juice and then added a little more than half of the sauce to them and gave them a stir before pouring them into the pie crust. I brushed the remaining sauce over the lattice top- just so we didn't miss out on the crust everyone was mentioning.
This pie was fantastic! I was a little afraid that it was going to be too sweet, but Grandma Ople sure knew what she was doing! Perfection. Thank you so much for sharing this recipe. It will be gracing many tables in the future!

country:
None
text:
This was delicious!  Made for Thanksgiving and everyone raved about it.  I added cinnamon to the apples because I like my cinnamon in an apple pie :-)  Otherwise I made it exactly as the recipe stated.  8 apples was the right amount for a 9 inch deep dish.  Next time, I will probably slice the apples a little thinner and use a mix of apples instead of all granny smith as they were just a little too tart and a little too firm.  I will also probably pour most of the sauce on the apples directly and then brush some on the lattice work after.  I think the lattice work really does visually make this pie - it is worth the extra effort and is really not that difficult - check out instructions on youtube if you've never done it before :-)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
i know everyone keeps saying this pie is delish.... its because it is and i will say it too! only reason for 4 stars is because it really does need i little help.  After peeling and slicing my apples (i used 3 green and 2 regular red apples) I put them in a bowl with 1 tbs cinnamon and 1 tbs lemon juice and mixed them all together and let it sit while doing the rest.  For the sauced i did add 1 tbs cinnamon and 1 tbs vanilla (and took out 1 tbs of water) which i think did the trick for the runny sauce because it was perfect.  i tossed the sauce in the bowl of apples and mixed it in before I filled the pie. (egg wash really does help prevent soggy crust inside) and brushed excess sauce all over outer crust. baked the entire time at 350 for 55 min on the middle rack.   My husband isnt a pie fan but let me tell you, half the pie was gone in a matter of minutes!!

dateLastModified:

userID:
7176875
Display Name:
Bela82
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
33
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/961846.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first apple pie EVER.  My husband does not like apple pie but this one he cant get enough of!!  I followed everyone's advice and added 1 tsp. cinnamon, 1/2 tsp. nutmeg and 1 tsp. vanilla but I added it to the sugar/butter mixture instead.  I simmered it for 5min as asked then turned off the heat, let it cool just a little and then added cinnamon, vanilla and nutmeg.  I didnt make my own crust (in case my first attempt sucked) and bought those pie shells.  As I stared to lay out the apples along the bottom of the shell in an overlapping spiral, I would spoon the mixture over each layer.  8 apples turned out to be too much but I did get slightly larger than average apples so 6 did me nicely.  Poured the remainder of the sauce on top of the apples (I piled them slightly to make sure that the second pie shell can fit easily over it upside-down) and topped with the other pie shell (do not remove the tin cover from it until last 20min of baking to prevent over browning).  It actually took 50-55min for me not 35-45 but it may be different because I have a gas stove.  DEFINITELY put the whole thing on a cookie sheet as it WILL leak.  Set it out to cool and only once it cools, break the top pie shell into chunks with a fork.  Et Voila!  Bon Apetit!

text:
I'm sure this tastes great as written, but I made just a few tweaks! First, I tossed 1 tsp cinnamon and 1/2 tsp nutmeg in with the chopped apples. I followed the recipe for the sugar/flour/butter mixture, using margarine as that was all I had on hand.  BUT, I poured this over the apples BEFORE I put the crust on. Then I gently glazed the remaining mixture on the crust (used French Pastry Pie Crust). Baked with the times suggested! TASTES AMAZING!!!!!!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm sure this tastes great as written, but I made just a few tweaks! First, I tossed 1 tsp cinnamon and 1/2 tsp nutmeg in with the chopped apples. I followed the recipe for the sugar/flour/butter mixture, using margarine as that was all I had on hand.  BUT, I poured this over the apples BEFORE I put the crust on. Then I gently glazed the remaining mixture on the crust (used French Pastry Pie Crust). Baked with the times suggested! TASTES AMAZING!!!!!!!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a lovely recipe for what it is, but people must take into account that this is a traditional apple pie, hence the omission of cinnamon. I will rate it 5 stars for the traditional recipe that it is. That being said, I would add 3/4 to 1 tbsp of cinnamon and 1/2 tsp of nutmeg to the apples for my taste. Don't add it to the sugar/butter if you want a pie with a perfect non-muddy brown appearance. This turned out amazing and was a real crowd pleaser. If you are going to make homemade apple pie, don't scrimp on the crust. Go homemade! You can do it!!

userID:
4462283
Display Name:
What's for dinner, mom?
isPro:
False
followersCount:
11593
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
555
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3274570.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This had to be the BEST smelling apple pie ever!  My family kept asking  "Mmmmm, what is THAT"?  Even my neighbor could smell it baking!  I used a variety of apples and topped it with the Fruit Pie Crumb Topping from this site.  The pie was not overly juicy where the juices run out once cut and they were well retained within the filling.  It sliced beautifully!  I don't like it when you mound the apples, top with the crust and once baked the crust stays high and mounded while the apples sink.  The Fruit Pie Crumb Topping worked out great!  I did not want it to over bake so I cooked my pie without any topping for 30 minutes.  I then pressed the apples down a bit and loaded up the crumb topping.  I finished the pie for the directed baking time and my crumb topping came out perfectly moist and not crunchy.  The pie sank like expected and the crumb topping stayed on top and didn't have that empty space between it and the apples.  The best recipe we have ever had for apple pie! Perfect, don't change a thing!!

text:
Fantastic. My first pie/pastry/dessert (I'm a new cook). Splendid outcome.  As suggested by many, I added cinnamon (1/2 tsp), vanilla extract (1 tsp) & nutmeg (1/4 tsp) to the sauce. Put 3/4 of sauce on apples and 1/4 over lattice pastry (allrecipes' "Basic Flaky Pie Crust" recipe - another 5-star classic).  Only thing I will do differently next time is MIX the sauce and the apples as suggested by others.  Couldn't wait 4-5 hours for it to cool ... my son & I waited 30 mins and then got stuck into a very juicy but fantastic pie.  Recipe deserves its accolades, thanks Moshasmama.

text:
Delicious and easy! The hardest part about it was peeling the apples (I don't have a mechanism to do it). I like the apples to be soft and this is the first recipe that actually made them soft (I sliced the apples VERY thinly). If you still like them a little crisp, you can make the apple slices a little thicker. Betty Crocker has nothing on this recipe! I also added some cinnamon to the butter/sugar mixture and it was yummy. Rave reviews from my friends and family and while it's not like this recipe is drastically different from anything I've ever tried, it's still the BEST!

text:
I am about to make this pie for the second time, and I can't wait! It was sooo good last time. I agree with the others about never needing 8 apples and adding cinnamon. I love the lattice crust and my husband is impressed by it!   One tip-- no need to prebake the crust, but definitely lightly sprinkle the inside of the bottom crust with plain old white sugar. It keeps it from getting soggy and even slightly caramelizes. Delicious!

text:
Yum!  I made this pie last year and didn't like it.  Afraid I have been used to frozen Mrs. Smiths for so long.  Then I decided to make again, but saw from a review on another apple pie recipe that it is best to use a variety of different apples.  I used Macintosh, Jonathan & Cortland apples.  I added 2 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp nutmeg and 1 tsp vanilla to the apples.  I poured most of mixture over apples and reserved about 1/4 c to put on top of crust (did not do lattice, but just cut slits into pie).  It was so good!  Thank you for the recipe and thanks to other reviewers for their helpful tips!  Cooked 15 min at 425 and then 35 at 350 and it was perfectly done!

Really good pie.  I do wish there were instructions on how long to cook the sugar mixture.  I think I cooked mine too long and then corrected it by adding a little water. Use a foil lined baking sheet underneath your pie pan!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my apple pie recipe from now on! It is sooooo delicious and it looked so gorgeous when it came out the oven I had to take a picture. I followed the recipe exactly, the only thing I added was to mix 1 1/2 tsp. cinnamon and 1/2 tsp. nutmeg in with the apples and to brush milk on the top of the crust before pouring the sugar mixture on. Next time, I will also brush milk on the bottom of the crust as other reviewers have suggested, to keep it from becoming soggy. Definitely follow the recipe and pour the sugar mixture on top of the pie. It makes the crust come out all sweet and crunchy and makes for an excellent presentation- I think it even helps to hide any imperfections in your lattice crust! Another tip- place a cookie sheet under the pie while baking. This pie is very juicy and some of the juices spill while baking.

Fantastic!!!  I followed the tips of other reviewers re: tossing the cinnamon & vanilla into the peeled apples first, and also the tip about pouring most of the caramel sauce over the apples (after they're in the bottom crust), and then after placing the top crust on, brushing the remaining caramel sauce on top (instead of sprinkling with sugar). My family LOVED this pie!!!  And it was so beautiful!  Best pie I've ever made!

userID:
2318756
Display Name:
klt14
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
18
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I went through a lot of trouble to find the perfect crust recipe. It is very tedious,but turns out a delicious buttery flaky crust. I needed a recipe for the pie filling and found this. I used it because of all the great reviews. First I found the fact that this recipe does not call for vanilla, cinnamon, or nutmeg odd, so I added it. Otherwise I followed the directions directly. I am an experienced baker.Even though the apples are not pre-cooked in this recipe, like called for in many others, they turn out mushy. It was like eating applesauce between ruined pie crust. The pie crust was ruined by the thick sugar sauce you pour over the lattice. Not only does the sauce make the top crust very hard, it lends little to no flavor to the pie and makes it look anything but appetizing. The pie looked burned when it was finished.I'm a big fan of Mrs. Smith's deep dish apple pie. It's becoming harder to find in supermarkets and I have a growing passion for baking. I'm used to a nice flaky crust with somewhat firm apples and a sweet cinnamon taste. This pie completely missed the mark. Attempt at your own risk.
Review:
Rating:
1
dateLastModified:
2007-11-28T15:44:40.503
helpfulCount:
3

text:
I went through a lot of trouble to find the perfect crust recipe. It is very tedious,but turns out a delicious buttery flaky crust. I needed a recipe for the pie filling and found this. I used it because of all the great reviews. First I found the fact that this recipe does not call for vanilla, cinnamon, or nutmeg odd, so I added it. Otherwise I followed the directions directly. I am an experienced baker.Even though the apples are not pre-cooked in this recipe, like called for in many others, they turn out mushy. It was like eating applesauce between ruined pie crust. The pie crust was ruined by the thick sugar sauce you pour over the lattice. Not only does the sauce make the top crust very hard, it lends little to no flavor to the pie and makes it look anything but appetizing. The pie looked burned when it was finished.I'm a big fan of Mrs. Smith's deep dish apple pie. It's becoming harder to find in supermarkets and I have a growing passion for baking. I'm used to a nice flaky crust with somewhat firm apples and a sweet cinnamon taste. This pie completely missed the mark. Attempt at your own risk.

Tastes just like my grandmothers used to, and I've been searching for that taste for 35 years. I used honeycrisp apples and they were perfect for this pie. Next time I will try LadyJayPee's method of additional low temp baking to get the apples more done; also I will mix all the flour/sugar mixture with the apples instead of reserving part for the top. I added vanilla & cinnamon to the liquid. Outstanding recipe!

text:
I made two of these pies at once.  The first one I forgot to simmer the sugar mixture, AND forgot the water, but the pie still turned out delicous!!!  The second time I followed the recipe almost, just shook the apples in a bit of cinnamon and sugar (as previously suggested) and tossed them in the sugar mixture before baking and brushed the lattice top with the rest of the mixture.  It turned out ALMOST as good as the first, I found it just a bit too sweet with the extra sugar on the apples. 
You can't go wrong with this recipe, everyone who tried them loved them!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe several times and it comes out perfect each time.  I do a few different things, though.  My Granny Smith apples are sometimes very sour, so I add about 1/8 - 1/4 cup more white sugar to my recipe.  I also add about 1 teaspoon of ground cinnamon as well, with a pinch of all spice.  I mix half of the sugar/butter mixture with the apples... then pour the other half over the lattice top to make it a bit easier.  Make sure to put a baking sheet under your pie as it bubbles over each time I make it.  This is an excellent recipe and have been requested to bring this pie for pot lucks.  Thanks for the recipe!!
Review:

userID:
845657
Display Name:
MWSEABRITE
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
32
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you'd like a picture worthy pie - try this recipe!  It's not only beautiful, it's delicious.  The only change i made was adding 1 tsp. of pumpkin pie spice to the apples and pouring HALF of the sauce inside the crust and the other half on the outside.  And as one reviewer advised, i used a pastry brush to cover the entire lattice crust.  this is what gives the pie that glossy, deep golden color so be sure not to skip this step.  i used a ready made crust in from the supermarket dairy case that has 2 in a box. you just unfold them and put them on your pie pan.  I also used a very nifty device that saves so much time when making a lattice style crust.  it's a pie crust sized cookie cutter with a checkerboard pattern on the inside.  u press down on your crust and poke out the little squares - whala! lattice like crust in seconds!  be sure to look for it at home stores if you like lattice crusts.  this tool is worth it's weight in gold - and so is this recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2003-09-23T07:51:38.287

text:
If you'd like a picture worthy pie - try this recipe!  It's not only beautiful, it's delicious.  The only change i made was adding 1 tsp. of pumpkin pie spice to the apples and pouring HALF of the sauce inside the crust and the other half on the outside.  And as one reviewer advised, i used a pastry brush to cover the entire lattice crust.  this is what gives the pie that glossy, deep golden color so be sure not to skip this step.  i used a ready made crust in from the supermarket dairy case that has 2 in a box. you just unfold them and put them on your pie pan.  I also used a very nifty device that saves so much time when making a lattice style crust.  it's a pie crust sized cookie cutter with a checkerboard pattern on the inside.  u press down on your crust and poke out the little squares - whala! lattice like crust in seconds!  be sure to look for it at home stores if you like lattice crusts.  this tool is worth it's weight in gold - and so is this recipe!

text:
I am so proud that I made a successful apple pie using this recipe. This is my husband's favorite dessert, and I had all but given up after several tries over the years, I had decided I was not a pie maker.  However, I made this one; only change: apple juice in place of water, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, and a solid crust instead of lattice.  Voila! Perfect and delicious.  I enjoyed the entire experience, and hubby is still enjoying the pie.  Good thing we had French Vanilla ice cream in the freezer to top it off!  Thank you for posting this recipe. Next I will try my hand with a lattice crust.  Did Grandma Ople have a peach pie recipe, by any chance?  Because that is my favorite!

userID:

Display Name:
Meghan
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this pie twice now, after the first was I was asked to make one for a co-workers birthday pie.  I took some others advice and added just a tsp of cinnamon to the apples in a bowl and stirred it around I also added just a sprinkle of allspice to the apples and stirred.  I took the advice and had the pie prepped though and ready before I started the sugar mixture on the stove.  That way once that was ready I could just pour over the pie and put in the over quickly, once that starts cooling down it will not pour easily and your will have a mess on your hands.  Get your apples peeled and cut and in the crust with the lattice top ready before you work the sugar mixture (best advice I read).  This turned out absolutely gorgeous and tasty.  I will be making this recipe for years to come.  THANKS for a great recipe....

text:
Not usually a pie maker but my family loves them so I gave this one a shot and boy were we all very happy.  This apple pie is so easy to make and super delicious.  We loved the Carmel mixture you pour over the apples.  We used fresh picked apples from our recent apple picking trip and sprinkled cinnamon over them.  Used a store bought pie shell and we did not do lattice work as to make it easier and it still came awesome.  Thanks for this recipe grandma Ople, My family loved it!!!

text:
Family pleaser! I've looked for years for a good apple pie recipe and this is it!  Only modified the recipe by stirring the apples with the sauce in a separate bowl before adding to the pie crust to evenly coat all the apples pieces.  Then placed apple mixture into the pie pan, used 1/4 stick of cold better and cut into small pieces and dropped onto apples and then sprinkled apples with cinnamon.  Instead of a top crust, cut pieces of dough and also dropped onto top of apple mixture.  More cobbler like, but can't say enough about how good it tasted!

text:
I am not really a fan of apple pie, but I made this (with no modifications except for using a mix of apples) for a 4th of July family cookout (what's more American than Apple Pie?) and it was really good! I used a deep dish frozen pie crust (brushed with milk as advised), and roll-up refrigerated crust for my lattice.     

Everyone loved it and it looked absolutely amazing... So amazing that I took pictures & sent them to my friends! Thanks Grandma Ople!

text:
I am not really a fan of apple pie, but I made this (with no modifications except for using a mix of apples) for a 4th of July family cookout (what's more American than Apple Pie?) and it was really good! I used a deep dish frozen pie crust (brushed with milk as advised), and roll-up refrigerated crust for my lattice.     

Everyone loved it and it looked absolutely amazing... So amazing that I took pictures & sent them to my friends! Thanks Grandma Ople!

text:
Make sure your apples are as crisp as possible.  If they are the least bit mushy, you will get a cobler rather than a pie (still tastes wonderful, but to runny to serve as a pie)

text:
Couldn't ask for a better apple pie. I used salted butter as well as added dashes of salt and cinnamon. I also added some blackberries. Only complaint is that the pie was runny. Maybe I could of cooked it longer or do less sauce? I mixed half of the sauce with the apples and drizzled the remaining sauce on top. I did a crumb topping so I did 1/2 cup of sugar inside and 1/2 cup for the crumb top (mixed with flour cinnamon and butter). Next time I made this recipe I am going to try to do 1/4 less sugar

text:
I almost hesitate to rate this since it already has so many good ratings. However, as I'm getting ready to make another pie, I just had to share. 

This pie was Amazing!  The sauce that goes on the pie is like the best caramel-y sauce ever. I could literally eat it with a spoon by itself.

Everyone so far has enjoyed this pie. The *only* thing I changed in the recipe is that I split the apples between Granny Smith and Golden Delicious, just to reduce the tartness just a bit.

Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This was the very first fruit pie I ever made!  I made a homemade crust for it and then followed the recipe exactly - except adding a teaspoon of cinnamon. 

My family LOVES it.  I mean, I got comments like 'best ever' from my dad and brother; 'restaurant quality' from my daughter. 

Great recipe! Super easy - just make sure you use a firm apple and you thicken up the caramel sauce well.

text:
Definitely the best apple pie! I also followed some of the advices here, such as adding cinnamon, nutmeg and vanilla to the apples and some cloves. The main thing I would do differently is that I would not do the lattice; instead, would covered the apples with the entire top crust and I would add all the syrup to the apples.  I think the lattice gets too crunchy. I used 3 gala apples, 3 machintosh and 3 greanny.

text:
Not much of a baker until 2 years ago and pies are a fav. I have made this as is 2x and also tweaked it a time or two. Best to me is a homemade butter double crust with Northern Spy or Jonagolds, 1 -2 Tbsp of lemon juice over apples makes a brighter flavor and 1 tsp of cinnamon. But you cannot go wrong if making it as is, it's that good!!! Thanx G'Ma Ople!

userID:

Display Name:
Chapin

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is amazing.  Every time I make it people freak out about how good it is.  I add in cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg to the portion of the butter-flour-sugar mixture mixed in with the apples.  I think it's important to toss the apples with the mixture and not just pour on top.  Also, be very careful not to overheat the butter-sugar mixture and make sure you have everything completely ready to go - crust, apples - before you start the butter-flour-sugar mix, because the mixture will become caramelized and too tough to work with very quickly.

I don't usually do a lattice pie, but just a standard double crust with some leaf cutouts for decoration.

Make this pie, you'll never be sorry!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-11-13T10:32:42.197

text:
This recipe is amazing.  Every time I make it people freak out about how good it is.  I add in cinnamon, cloves and nutmeg to the portion of the butter-flour-sugar mixture mixed in with the apples.  I think it's important to toss the apples with the mixture and not just pour on top.  Also, be very careful not to overheat the butter-sugar mixture and make sure you have everything completely ready to go - crust, apples - before you start the butter-flour-sugar mix, because the mixture will become caramelized and too tough to work with very quickly.

I don't usually do a lattice pie, but just a standard double crust with some leaf cutouts for decoration.

Make this pie, you'll never be sorry!

text:
I have been looking for a good apple pie recipe for ages, and this one is perfect.  I braided the top loosely so that the sugar mix would drip into the pie.  Everyone loved this one, my mother-in-law even asked me for the recipe after trying it.  Make sure to use unsalted butter, and use apples that are a bit tart.. I used MacIntosh since they were in season.  I also learned that in order for it to cook properly, cook on the lowest rack in the oven.  Best recipe I've tried so far, and it's going into my recipe box!

text:
This pie is delicious. It's always a hit when I bake it for parties and get-togethers. I do usually make a few modifications.  I sprinkled cinnamon and vanilla onto the apple slices after I spread them in the crust. I also don't use a lattice crust. I felt like the crust taste would overpower the taste of the apples. Lastly, 8 apples is too many. I use something like 5 or 6 large apples.

text:
I've never made a pie before.  I'm the girl who's forgotten to add flour to cookies.  In this way, I am no baker (even less of a cook).  However, a friend gave us a box of 100 + apples (gravenstein apples, mostly) and I figured I was bored enough to give it a shot.  Needles to say, and to my great surprise, I ate most the pie myself...that night!  I've never had anything like this in my life, absolutley amazing.    Strangely, I hate pies as does my friend, and neither of us could put this down.  I'm a changed woman.  The only changes I made was using salted butter instead of unsalted, using sweeter apples, and then dusting the apples in a little white sugar and cinnamon.   Now I'm just sad that I finished the last slice :(

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been baking for 40+ years and have made countless apple pies.  This is an awesome recipe. Who knew what pouring that hot syrup over my chilled lattice crust would do. WOW!  So important the crust be lattice.  I made the pie dough, rolled out bottom crust , put in pie plate , cut the strips and placed on a platter on wax paper, put all in the refrigerator to keep  chilled . I sliced the apples , added little lemon juice, fresh nutmeg and cinnamon and set aside, THEN made the syrup, that way no mistakes in consistency. It should pour freely over the pie, pour slowly.  This is absolutely the best apple pie I have ever made, and will use the same technique with my pear pies.  Grandma Ople knew what she was doing!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This pie is fantastic!  I do change it up a bit though.  I add my sliced apples to the sauce on the stove to get them nice and tender before putting them in the oven.  I can't stand apple pie that has crunchy apples in it.  Secondly I add about 2-3 teaspoons of cinnamon and a teaspoon of vanilla extract.  After the pie is finished baking the sauce is so delicious...almost like a cinnamon caramel sauce.

This is, by far, the BEST apple pie recipe I have ever made. My husband loves it. I also mix the sauce into the apples and then pour into piecrust.  This is the only apple pie I will be making from now on!

country:
None
text:
My husband, not a fan of pumpkin pie, loves this pie -- and I have to say, it doesn't make me miss pumpkin.  You'll definitely want to invest in an apple peeler and corer (@ $16 at Amazon), but with that and a pre-made (frozen) pie crust, the prep was about 20 minutes for me.  I also don't do the lattice on top, I made a crumb topping (half cup each of flour & brown sugar, stirred together, then cut in 3T of unsalted butter).  The apples mound HUGE in the crust, so pouring the sauce requires a very slow approach, but everything should fit and not run over when done.  The cooked sauce gives it a sweet caramel-y flavor, and heating it up a day later and adding whipped cream is definitely the way to go.

text:
What a great Pie.   Very good.  I have read many of the reviews and some good tips.  Some saying leave as is others saying add your common pie spices.  I say make it how you like it.  I made it once with no extras and once with my normal apple pie spices (cinni, nutmeg, and a touch of allspice)  every time it came out great.  I would highly suggest always using a lattice top crust,  you dont have to, but if you don't you might at well add the sugar and butter to the apples and bake like a normal pie.  Also i would suggest trying other apples.  There are so may great varieties. Just make sure the are more on the tart side since you will need to off set the sugars.  I suggest honey crisp and braeburn two of my favorites.  Or like I like to do mix it up 8 apples try 2 of a few.  Just some thoughts.

This was a great apple pie and super easy to make. I just can't believe there is no cinnamon in this recipe. I made the recipe as is but will make sure to add cinnamon next time. It just gives it that extra flavor. Served with vanilla ice cream and caramel sauce.

text:
I wanted all of the juicy goodness to be inside the pie, so I stirred the sauce into the apples and then filled the pie shell and sealed with a traditional crust.  The pie still came out a bit dry.  It was a good pie, but not anything I would rave about.  Maybe my apples were larger.  It would be nice to use weights instead of amounts in this recipe since sizes of apples vary so much.  Next time, I'll try to increase the sauce by half and see if that works.  It also needs about 2 tsp cinnamon.

text:
Easy pie to make.  Simple and delicious.  Use the ready made pie crust when you are short on time.  I added cinnamon, a pinch of nutmeg and 1 tablespoon of vanilla.  I mixed the apples in the sauce before putting them in the pie shell.  Then I saved some of the sauce and spread it on the top of the crust before cooking.  My husband loved the crust that way.  Thank you for sharing this recipe.

text:
This is a great recipe.  The pie was beautiful with the carmel topping browned on the crust.  I love cinnamon in my apple pies, so I added some of that.  If you do make this pie, I would recommend serving it warm.  I made it the night before and by the time we ate it the next evening, the butter/caramel sauce had hardened on top with liquid underneath. Everyone still loved it though.

text:
After making this pie for several years, at the request of family for the holidays, this is the only recipe I will use.  My grandfather loves it!  There are a few changes I have made to make it even better.  First, add the 1 tsp of cinnamon or apple pie spice to the sauce and coat the apples with 3/4 of the sauce prior to turning into your pie dish.  Pour the remaining 1/4 over the lattice top.  If I have it on hand, I replace the water with apple cider, which gives the sauce a really nice flavor.  You can also convert this recipe to make apple dumplings baked in the sweet apple sauce too!

text:
5 stars!  I was afraid that the pie would be too sweet but it was just right--I did use salted butter in place of unsalted.  I also used Stayman-Winesap apples from a recent apple-picking excursion instead of the Grannys.  I followed the recipe otherwise, no cinnamon, no nutmeg.  I poured half of the sauce over the apples and the rest over the latticework crust.  That was the best part!  The caramel sauce really makes a sweet-tasting, buttery, soft but slightly crunchy-on-top crust.  Make sure you put a cookie sheet underneath the pie as per other reviewers, there was a lot of overflow.

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious apple pie recipe.
I only made a few modifications based off of other reviewers. First of all, I mixed the sugar/butter into the apples rather than pouring it on top. Then I used an egg white to brush the top of the pie to make it a nice golden brown. Also, I reduced the sugar to 1/3 cup of each white and brown rather than the 1/2 cup each. I used the pate brisee recipe from marthastewart.com and it turned out flaky, golden brown, and delicious. I would definitely recommend this recipe to make. I also added a bit of nutmeg, as well as some cinnamon to the apples.

Overall this recipe was very easy and I made it all by myself, even though I am only 14. I used apples from my friend's apple tree (anna apples) and left the skin on for color.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Delicious apple pie recipe.
I only made a few modifications based off of other reviewers. First of all, I mixed the sugar/butter into the apples rather than pouring it on top. Then I used an egg white to brush the top of the pie to make it a nice golden brown. Also, I reduced the sugar to 1/3 cup of each white and brown rather than the 1/2 cup each. I used the pate brisee recipe from marthastewart.com and it turned out flaky, golden brown, and delicious. I would definitely recommend this recipe to make. I also added a bit of nutmeg, as well as some cinnamon to the apples.

Overall this recipe was very easy and I made it all by myself, even though I am only 14. I used apples from my friend's apple tree (anna apples) and left the skin on for color.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!!  I tweaked it, only because I'm adventurous.  I combined this recipe with another I found on the web for an apple/craisin/cherry/pecan/ bourbon pie.  I soaked dried raisins and cherries in a cup of bourbon overnight.  After toasting the pecans for about 10 minutes, I added them and the bourbon mix to the flour/sugar/butter/apple juice (substituted that for the water) mix along with some cinnamon and vanilla.  I also steamed the apples to soften just a little.  I mixed everything together and then added about 2 T of heavy cream to the mixture to smooth everything out.  I was told I should sell the pie, it was so good!  :)  This combination is what I'll be making from now on...  thanks to the original recipe by Grandma Ople.

I made two of these in the fall with orchard apples and froze them. If you set them on the counter for a few hours and then bake, they are delicious!

text:
WAY too much butter.. the sauce was so rich it completely dominated the apples.  I'm more of naturalist or a purist or whatever you want to call it, so I believe the spices or sauce should just enhance/ compliment the flavor of the apples; they shouldn't completely take over like the did in this recipe.  Perhaps if the butter and amount of sauce were decreased.

text:
I made this pie for Thanksgiving and it was a "semi" hit. It was slightly runny as another person wrote in so I would definitely add maybe 1-2T flour to the apples. I also did pour 1/2 the sugar mixture into the apples and the rest over the top of the crust. It looked awesome coming out of the oven! Also, I would use Fuji apples instead of the Granny Smith . They seem to hold their shape good and not get smushy. Anyway, I certainly recommend the recipe and I will try again. Happy Thanksgiving!

None
text:
Very good as is. I agree with those who say to wait and try it before adding spices. The only thing I added was a sprinkle of coarse sanding sugar over the crust. The crust on the pie is delicious and beautiful! If your pie is turning out mushy and runny, it could be because of the apples you are using. Tarter apples hold up better in pies...a lot of apples will just turn to mush. So stick to Granny Smiths or other very tart apples.  I used Red Haralsons from the tree in my yard and they worked perfectly.
Review:

text:
The kids were have a great time practicing their fire safety exercises "stop, drop, and roll" while I was making this pie after the kitchen filled with smoke from the caramel sauce that spilled over onto the bottom of the oven.  After the smoke detectors ceased their alarms and the pie cooled, we all enjoyed a most delicious apple heaven!  This is a truly wonderful pie!  Just don't forget to put something underneath to catch the overflowing sauce!

text:
Easiest and greatest pie I've ever had!  Like others I sprinkled my apples with cinnamon put them in my crust and then poured the sugar mixture over my pie.  Also I've found that baking it for closer to 45 minutes (after baking it at 425 degrees for 15 min.) makes for the best pie.  When baking it for 35 my apples just weren't as tender as I would have liked them to be.  Overall a wonderful apple pie recipe!

text:
I was so worried that my pie wasn't going to turn out well at all.  My crust before baked, was very tangy tasting as it called for vinegar, I used Bakers Secret Pie crust from this site.  I used the full 8 apples and used a deep dish pie plate which was piled high but thats good, it cooks down.  I mixed quite a bit of the mixture in with the apples as I didn't know about putting all on top of the crust especially since i didn't lattice it.  i did brush some on top and had made several slits on the top.  I was worried about that too as i thought it was going to be very "carmely" tasting.  Boy was I wrong, and happily so!!  This is by far the best pie I have ever made or eaten for that matter and my husbands Mom is a superb baker.  I could eat the crust and the filling alone they're both excellent.  The sauce is the yummiest on top of the crust, next time, more is going on top!  Mine took over an hour as it was very thick. It took my husband and I only 4 nights to finish it off! YUMMO!!

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
2
userID:
1809535
Display Name:
Renee
isPro:
False
followersCount:
8
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
48
favoritesCount:
51
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This pie is phenomenal as it is, but I made some adjustments. Instead of 1/2 cup of butter, I use 1/2 cup applesauce and 1 T butter for more apple flavor and nutrition. I followed another reviewer's advice and mix the apples with 1 T cinnamon, a sprinkle of freshly grated nutmeg, 1 t vanilla extract, and the juice of half a lemon for a nice bite and to prevent browning. I also sprinkle a little sugar on the bottom of the crust for crisp before adding the apples and pour all of the sauce directly on the apples, not the crust. Then for the crust, which I don't take the time to do lattice-style, I make a few slits, brush with milk, and sprinkle with sugar. I then cover the edges of the crust with tin foil to prevent burning and place on a baking stone lined with foil (placed in the oven prior to baking to heat up and ensure oven temp) to help cook the bottom of the crust. After the 40 minutes at 350, I remove the tinfoil from the crust and keep the pie in the oven for 30 minutes at about 250 to help evaporate some of the excess liquid and finish cooking the edges of the crust. This is so delicious!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-07-20T02:50:30.97

text:
This pie is phenomenal as it is, but I made some adjustments. Instead of 1/2 cup of butter, I use 1/2 cup applesauce and 1 T butter for more apple flavor and nutrition. I followed another reviewer's advice and mix the apples with 1 T cinnamon, a sprinkle of freshly grated nutmeg, 1 t vanilla extract, and the juice of half a lemon for a nice bite and to prevent browning. I also sprinkle a little sugar on the bottom of the crust for crisp before adding the apples and pour all of the sauce directly on the apples, not the crust. Then for the crust, which I don't take the time to do lattice-style, I make a few slits, brush with milk, and sprinkle with sugar. I then cover the edges of the crust with tin foil to prevent burning and place on a baking stone lined with foil (placed in the oven prior to baking to heat up and ensure oven temp) to help cook the bottom of the crust. After the 40 minutes at 350, I remove the tinfoil from the crust and keep the pie in the oven for 30 minutes at about 250 to help evaporate some of the excess liquid and finish cooking the edges of the crust. This is so delicious!

text:
I've been making this pie for years now.  I've used every type of apple, and it always receives rave reviews.  I love the way it makes the house smell.  Like Cinnabon!  Now that I have the perfect filling recipe, I can only aspire to making the perfect crust.  Until then, it's store bought, and the latice top is always a hit.  Blue Ribbon perfection!  Thanks for sharing!
